description: An apple is an edible fruit produced by an apple tree (Malus domestica). Apple trees are cultivated worldwide and are the most widely grown species in the genus Malus

The orange is the fruit of various citrus species in the family Rutaceae, it primarily refers to Citrus × sinensis, which is also called sweet orange, to distinguish it from the related Citrus × aurantium, referred to as bitter orange. The sweet orange reproduces asexually, varieties of sweet orange arise through mutations

Bread is a staple food prepared from a dough of flour and water, usually by baking. Throughout recorded history, it has been a prominent food in large parts of the world. It is one of the oldest human-made foods, having been of significant importance since the dawn of agriculture
Capsicums are native to tropical America. They then spread to Europe but they have only been available in New Zealand for the past 30-40 years.
Carrots have been a staple in many countries for thousands of years although it is only since the 16th century that they have been orange.
Cucumbers are thought to have originated in Southern Asia and were very popular in India.
Ginger originated in the southern provinces of China and India, where it has been used in food and medicines for over 5,000 years.
There are hundreds of varieties of melons, however, the four most popular in New Zealand are watermelon, honeydew, prince melon and rockmelon
Mushrooms have been eaten in Europe, Russia, China and Japan for thousands of years.
Onions are the most used flavouring vegetable in the world.
A banana is a curved, yellow fruit with a thick skin and soft sweet flesh. If you eat a banana every day for breakfast, it gives all your everyday vitamins
The name radish is derived from the Latin words ‘radix’ meaning root, and ‘raphanus’ meaning easily grown.
Spring onions belong to the onion family and in some countries they are known as scallions, bunching or green onions.
Tomatoes are native to South America and were originally grown for their decorative purposes.
Turmeric originated from the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia, and it requires subterranean temperatures and plentiful rain.
